Award.AwardTitle: AF: SMALL: Frontiers in Algorithmic Game Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent years have seen much of the world's economic activity transferred to the Internet through old markets that obtained online presence and new markets that are directly inspired and enabled by the Internet, such as sponsored search and ad auctions. Driven by the increasing importance of online economic activity, there has been much interest in investigating its joint computational and economic characteristics through research at the interface of Computer Science and Economics. Economics brought to the table quantitative models and methodology for studying economic systems. But it soon became clear that these models and methodology required adaptation, since the intention was to study systems that are computational while involving thousands or millions of participants. This thinking gave rise to the field of Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT), which has in the past fifteen years grown into a mature research discipline.

This project will identify and investigate new frontiers of research in this field, focusing on the following:

- Furthering our understanding of multi-item mechanisms by (i) weakening the distributional assumptions required for optimizing important objectives such as revenue; (ii) overcoming well-established computational intractability barriers for welfare maximization by moving away from truthful mechanisms to mechanisms solvable via online learning; and (iii) using optimal transport theory to characterize the structure of optimal mechanisms.

- Discerning the role of learning and signaling in auction settings, by understanding how to (i) learn a revenue-optimal auction from weak forms of sample access to the bidders' distributions, (ii) test the near-optimality of a given auction from samples, and (iii) further a line of research going back to classical works of Akerlof and Milgrom-Weber by investigating how to design optimal signaling schemes for the auctioneer to use in common settings, such as sponsored search, where the auctioneer owns information about the properties of the items that the bidders do not have.

- Finally, revisiting the computational foundations of the field, investigating the relation between Factoring and Nash equilibrium.

The work in Algorithmic Game Theory is inherently interdisciplinary. This project will further the interaction between Computer Science and Economics through the publication of the research outcomes in high-impact Economics journals, organization of interdisciplinary research meetings, interdisciplinary research collaborations, and research surveys. The educational component of the project will involve the mentoring and education of researchers who intend to pursue their own careers in research or industry, and the design of pioneering classes in the interface of Computer Science and Economics. Furthering the educational and outreach impact of the project, the PI will be mentoring high school students in Computer Science research through the MIT PRIMES program, will be engaged in Computer Science Unplugged activities at local elementary schools, and will engage with the broader public through public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied problems at the interface of Complexity, Optimization, Game Theory, Economics and Machine Learning. 

We improved our understanding of multi-item mechanisms on several fronts. While much of the work in Economics and Computer Science has studied truthful mechanisms, we developed tools for understanding the performance of non-truthful mechanisms, and for analyzing those mechanisms outside of equilibrium. This combined approach allowed us to overcome well-established computational intractability barriers for welfare maximization in multi-item settings. It has also enabled us to derive revenue guarantees for simple non-truthful mechanisms.

Moreover, classical work in Economics targets the design of good mechanisms under the assumption that a prior distribution about the bidders' preferences is common knowledge (known to the designer and all the biddres). We develop tools for designing mechanisms when that prior is only approximately known. This is challenging as mechanisms tend to be very sensitive to the fine details of the prior, and required us to develop a framework for robustifying a mechanism's performance against errors in the distribution.

Finally, much of the work on multi-item mechanisms assumes that bidders have independent values across items. We develop frameworks that accommodate dependencies across items, allowing the design of mechanisms when the prior is a Markov Random Field or a Bayesian Network.

A large focus of our project has also been on the interface of Complexity, Optimization, Game Theory and Machine Learning. We studied min-max optimization, a problem which has a rich history in Game Theory, Mathematical Programming and Online Learning as well as many applications in various theoretical and applied fields. The problem has also recently emerged as a key challenge in Deep Learning, arising naturally in training deep generative models (e.g. GANs) and building classifiers that are robust to adversarial attacks.

When the dimensionality of a min-maximization problem is large and its objective function is not convex, the problem becomes extremely challenging computationally. The standard approach is to have the min player run online gradient descent and the max player run online gradient ascent, in tandem. However, this is often unstable and this instability has been identified as a major hurdle in applications of min-maximization in Deep Learning. Our work advances the state of the art by providing methods that are provably convergent in the high-dimensional convex setting, provably more stable than current methods in the nonconvex setting, and practically better performing. We also provide intractability results delineating what min-maximization problems are tractable.

To improve the dissemination of our results and our outreach, we have given multiple invited lectures, keynotes, and public lectures. We have also been interviewed for documentaries, wide-circulation newspapers and magazines, and podcasts (including by two NPR Planet Money episodes on fair division and mechanism design).
